title: languages and diatrics
content:
I have the a list from stormtype wich shows diatrics for european languages.  
I wonder if there was a list available somewhere which shows every diatrics of the languages of the world ?

thanks in advance.
author: docunagi

comments.content:
The word you mean is diacritic. See here:

[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diacritic](http://web.archive.org/web/20100612222737/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diacritic "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diacritic")

Hey Nick, after all the uproar over the Huckabee commercial with the subliminal cross behind him, I'm beginning to wonder if you've got a messiah complex too.

[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KMUI2XExdIA](http://web.archive.org/web/20100612222737/http:/www.youtube.com/watch?v=KMUI2XExdIA "http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KMUI2XExdIA")

Unicode may be the most complete list of written symbols around, but its organization doesn't make for easy human browsing. Robert Bringhurst's "Working Alphabet", Appendix A in his _Elements of Typographic Style_, is limited to Roman, Greek, Cyrillic, and the International Phonetic Alphabet, but it's much easier to peruse.
